Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2015 06:46PM Mom2ABoy wrote: Chemotherapy doesn't have to be so difficult. Ask your MO whether you could do more frequent, low-dose chemo instead of three or four dose-dense infusions. I'm 3/4 of the way through a 12-week regimen of taxol, carboplatin and herceptin and have had hair loss, but no effects on my fingernails and very little neuropathy. (And honestly I think a good part of my hair loss is because of an injected medicine to keep my white blood cell counts up - my hair loss didn't start in earnest until I started this medicine.) Everyone is different of course, but this is an option that I don't think enough MO's mention to patients. Frankly I think it's because it's easier to schedule people for appointments every three weeks than every week. It's for the convenience of both the patient and the clinic,but seriously, what is convenience in the face of dose-dense side effects that can be so debilitating!

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2014 02:13PM Mom2ABoy wrote: Hi PMR53, I love the Seattle Cancer Treatment and Wellness Center! They coordinated treatment for my husband's cancer more than 12 years ago. They were our "final stop" -- our fourth opinion -- because each of the doctors we had seen before had offered very unsatisfactory ideas. They use a holistic, wellness-oriented approach that involves nutrition and complementary therapies as well as conventional treatment. Personally I think it's a shame that they don't have a hospital of their own in Seattle, but they did a great job of coordinating with the hospital we used for his surgery and conventional chemotherapy, which was Swedish. (Also fantastic doctors there.) The oncologist we saw at SCTWC now has his own practice, LifeSpring, which uses a similar approach. Anyway, if you want to know more about his treatment pathand why I think it worked so well, send me a PM, or post in the alternative treatments discussion forum.
